Roomba.h

00001 // Roomba.h
00002 //
00003 ///
00004 /// \mainpage Roomba library for Arduino
00005 ///
00006 /// This is the Arduino Roomba library.
00007 /// It provides an object-oriented interface for talking to iRobot Roomba and Create robots
00008 /// via a serial port.
00009 /// The Roomba is the original device from iRobot. It has a serial port DIN socket on the side.
00010 /// The Create is a more full-featured robot platform for hobbyists. It has both the DIN socket and a DB25
00011 /// connector called the CArgo Bay Connector
00012 ///
00013 /// The Create understands a superset of the Roomba commands. This library supports both devices. Where 
00014 /// comands are only available on one or the other platform it is noted.
00015 ///
00016 /// The version of the package that this documentation refers to can be downloaded 
00017 /// from http://www.open.com.au/mikem/arduino/Roomba/Roomba-1.1.zip
00018 /// You can find the latest version at http://www.open.com.au/mikem/arduino/Roomba
00019 ///
00020 /// Tested on Arduino Duemilanove, Diecimila and Mega with arduino-0018 on OpenSuSE 11.1 and avr-libc-1.6.1-1.15,
00021 /// cross-avr-binutils-2.19-9.1, cross-avr-gcc-4.1.3_20080612-26.5.
00022 ///
00023 /// A number of example programs are included that work with the iRobot Create:
00024 /// \li TestSuite Runs on a Mega and exercises a number of the functions, checking for correct operation
00025 /// \li RoombaTest1 Runs in any Arduino, checks that sensors can be read from Create using the stream() command
00026 /// \li RoombaRCRx Demo program that shows how to control a Create using the RCRx Arduino library,
00027 /// an Arduino WiFi shield such as BlackWidow and the RCTx 
00028 /// iPhone app. Control a Create from your iPhone!
00029 ///
00030 /// A video domonstating this library (along with the http://www.open.com.au/mikem/arduino/RCKit library)
00031 /// being used to control a Create from an iPhone or iPad can be found at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qv-5ZOb5WW4
00032 ///
00033 /// \par Installation
00034 /// Install in the usual way: unzip the distribution zip file to the libraries
00035 /// sub-folder of your sketchbook. 
00036 ///
00037 /// This software is Copyright (C) 2010 Mike McCauley. Use is subject to license
00038 /// conditions. The main licensing options available are GPL V2 or Commercial:
00039 /// 
00040 /// \par Open Source Licensing GPL V2
00041 /// This is the appropriate option if you want to share the source code of your
00042 /// application with everyone you distribute it to, and you also want to give them
00043 /// the right to share who uses it. If you wish to use this software under Open
00044 /// Source Licensing, you must contribute all your source code to the open source
00045 /// community in accordance with the GPL Version 2 when your application is
00046 /// distributed. See http://www.gnu.org/copyleft/gpl.html
00047 /// 
00048 /// \par Commercial Licensing
00049 /// This is the appropriate option if you are creating proprietary applications
00050 /// and you are not prepared to distribute and share the source code of your
00051 /// application. Contact info@open.com.au for details.
00052 ///
00053 /// \par Revision History
00054 /// \version 1.0 Initial release
00055 /// \version 1.1 Updated docs, added Youtube video
00056 ///
00057 /// \author  Mike McCauley (mikem@open.com.au)
00058 // Copyright (C) 2010 Mike McCauley
00059 // $Id: Roomba.h,v 1.1 2010/09/27 21:58:32 mikem Exp mikem $

00066 /// Masks for LEDs in leds()
00067 #define ROOMBA_MASK_LED_NONE    0
00068 #define ROOMBA_MASK_LED_PLAY    0x2
00069 #define ROOMBA_MASK_LED_ADVANCE 0x8
00070 
00071 /// Masks for digitalOut()
00072 #define ROOMBA_MASK_DIGITAL_OUT_0 0x1
00073 #define ROOMBA_MASK_DIGITAL_OUT_1 0x2
00074 #define ROOMBA_MASK_DIGITAL_OUT_2 0x4
00075 
00076 /// Masks for drivers()
00077 #define ROOMBA_MASK_DRIVER_0 0x1
00078 #define ROOMBA_MASK_DRIVER_1 0x2
00079 #define ROOMBA_MASK_DRIVER_2 0x4
00080 /// Roomba only:
00081 #define ROOMBA_MASK_SIDE_BRUSH 0x1
00082 #define ROOMBA_MASK_VACUUM     0x2
00083 #define ROOMBA_MASK_MAIN_BRUSH 0x4
00084 
00085 /// Masks for bumps and wheedrops sensor packet id 7
00086 #define ROOMBA_MASK_BUMP_RIGHT       0x1
00087 #define ROOMBA_MASK_BUMP_LEFT        0x2
00088 #define ROOMBA_MASK_WHEELDROP_RIGHT  0x4
00089 #define ROOMBA_MASK_WHEELDROP_LEFT   0x8
00090 #define ROOMBA_MASK_WHEELDROP_CASTER 0x10
00091 
00092 /// Masks for driver overcurrents Packet ID 13
00093 #define ROOMBA_MASK_LD1              0x1
00094 #define ROOMBA_MASK_LD0              0x2
00095 #define ROOMBA_MASK_LD2              0x4
00096 #define ROOMBA_MASK_RIGHT_WHEEL      0x8
00097 #define ROOMBA_MASK_LEFT_WHEEL       0x10
00098 // Roomba, use ROOMBA_MASK_SIDE_BRUSH,  ROOMBA_MASK_VACUUM, ROOMBA_MASK_MAIN_BRUSH
00099 
00100 /// Masks for buttons sensor packet ID 18
00101 /// Create
00102 #define ROOMBA_MASK_BUTTON_PLAY      0x1
00103 #define ROOMBA_MASK_BUTTON_ADVANCE   0x4
00104 /// Roomba
00105 #define ROOMBA_MASK_BUTTON_MAX       0x1
00106 #define ROOMBA_MASK_BUTTON_CLEAN     0x2
00107 #define ROOMBA_MASK_BUTTON_SPOT      0x4
00108 #define ROOMBA_MASK_BUTTON_POWER     0x8
00109 
00110 /// Masks for digital inputs sensor packet ID 32
00111 #define ROOMBA_MASK_DIGITAL_IN_0      0x1
00112 #define ROOMBA_MASK_DIGITAL_IN_1      0x2
00113 #define ROOMBA_MASK_DIGITAL_IN_2      0x4
00114 #define ROOMBA_MASK_DIGITAL_IN_3      0x8
00115 #define ROOMBA_MASK_DIGITAL_IN_DEVICE_DETECT      0x10
00116 
00117 /// Masks for charging sources sensor packet ID 34
00118 #define ROOMBA_MASK_INTERNAL_CHARGER  0x1
00119 #define ROOMBA_MASK_HOME_BASE         0x2

00121 /// \def ROOMBA_READ_TIMEOUT
00122 /// Read timeout in milliseconds.
00123 /// If we have to wait more than this to read a char when we are expecting one, then something is wrong.
00124 #define ROOMBA_READ_TIMEOUT 200

00130 /////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00131 /// \class Roomba Roomba.h <Roomba.h>
00132 /// \brief Support for iRobot Roomba and Create platforms via serial port using the iRobot Open Interface (OI)
00133 /// protocol.
00134 ///
00135 /// The iRobot Roomba and Create platforms support a serial port through which you can control and 
00136 /// interrogate the device. The protocol implemented here conforms to the Open Interface protocol described in the 
00137 /// iRobot Open Interface Command Reference. Not all commands are supported on both platforms. Differences are
00138 /// noted in the API
00139 ///
00140 /// The Roomba and Create is equipped with a min-din serial port socket, while the Create
00141 /// is also equipped with a 25-pin D connector called the Cargo Bay Connector. The
00142 /// pins on the Cargo Bay Connector include the serial port, battery, digital inputs and
00143 /// outputs, and an analog input.
00144 ///
00145 /// In order to communicate with a Roomba, you must create an instance of the Roomba class and then call its 
00146 /// instance methods to send commmands and receive sensor messages. You can also request continuous 
00147 /// streams of sensor data to be sent by the Roomba. The Roomba also emits messages on its 
00148 /// serial port from time to time as described below.
00149 ///
00150 /// \par Electrical Considerations
00151 ///
00152 /// The serial port output TXD from the Roomba/Create is too weak to drive the RX serial port input 
00153 /// of an Arduino properly.
00154 /// This is because of the USB-Serial converter on the Arduino: it also tries to drive the RX serial port input
00155 /// via a pullup resistor, 
00156 /// but the Roomba does not have enough drive to pull the RX down below about 2.5 volts, which is insufficient 
00157 /// to be reliably detected as a TTL serial input of 0.
00158 ///
00159 /// \note Note that this problem does not affect the Serial1 Serial2 or Serial3 ports on the Mega: these ports do not 
00160 /// have other circuitry connected to them and the Roomba can drive the serial port inputs of these ports 
00161 /// without a problem. Its only the RX Serial port (ie the first Serial port) that is affected by this problem. 
00162 ///
00163 /// What this means is that if you intend to connect a Roomba to the standard (first) RX/TX serial port on an Arduino 
00164 /// you \a MUST have additional circuitry to help drive RX on the Arduino low enough. 
00165 /// We use a simple PNP emitter follower. Almost any small signal low power PNP will do.
00166 /// See the <a href="Create-Arduino.pdf">example circuit diagram</a>. This will ensure the RX serial 
00167 /// port input on the Arduino is pulled down to about 0.6V for reliable comms.
00168 ///
00169 /// \par Other Roomba messages
00170 ///
00171 /// When iRobot Create powers up and after a reset, it sends a message like this on its serial port:
00172 /// \code
00173 /// bl-start
00174 /// 2006-09-12-1137-L   
00175 /// RDK by iRobot!
00176 /// MC9S12E128
00177 /// 2006-11-20-1731-L   
00178 /// battery-current-quiescent-raw 524  battery-current-zero 510
00179 /// 
00180 /// 2006-11-20-1731-L   
00181 /// \endcode
00182 ///
00183 /// While charging it will send a message like this each second:
00184 /// \code
00185 /// bat:   min 3  sec 21  mV 15558  mA 1491  deg-C 24  
00186 /// \endcode
00187 ///
00188 /// To enter the factory test menu for the IRobot Create, hold down the (>) and (>>|) 
00189 /// buttons then press and hold the Power button until the assending and descending tones play and then stop. 
00190 /// You wil see some messages emitted on teh serial port.
00191 /// Press the right-right arrow button to cycle through the tests.
00192 ///
00193 class Roomba
00194 {
00195 public:
00196     /// \enum Baud
00197     /// Demo types to pass to Roomba::baud()
00198     typedef enum
00199     {
00200         Baud300    = 0,
00201         Baud600    = 1,
00202         Baud1200   = 2,
00203         Baud2400   = 3,
00204         Baud4800   = 4,
00205         Baud9600   = 5,
00206         Baud14400  = 6,
00207         Baud19200  = 7,
00208         Baud28800  = 8,
00209         Baud38400  = 9,
00210         Baud57600  = 10,
00211         Baud115200 = 11,
00212     } Baud;
00213     
00214     /// \enum Demo
00215     /// Demo types to pass to Roomba::demo()
00216     typedef enum
00217     {
00218         DemoAbort = -1,
00219         DemoCover = 0,
00220         DemoCoverAndDock = 1,
00221         DemoSpotCover = 2,
00222         DemoMouse = 3,
00223         DemoDriveFigureEight = 4,
00224         DemoWimp = 5,
00225         DemoHome = 6,
00226         DemoTag = 7,
00227         DemoPachelbel = 8,
00228         DemoBanjo = 9,
00229     } Demo;
00230     
00231     /// \enum Drive
00232     /// Special values for radius in Roomba::drive()
00233     typedef enum
00234     {
00235         DriveStraight                = 0x8000,
00236         DriveInPlaceClockwise        = 0xFFFF,
00237         DriveInPlaceCounterClockwise = 0x0001,
00238     } Drive;
00239   
00240     /// \enum StreamCommand
00241     /// Values to pass to Roomba::streamCommand()
00242     typedef enum
00243     {
00244         StreamCommandPause  = 0,  
00245         StreamCommandResume = 1,
00246     } StreamCommand;
00247   
00248     /// \enum EventType
00249     /// Values to pass to Roomba::waitEvent()
00250     typedef enum
00251     {
00252         EventTypeWheelDrop       = 1,
00253         EventTypeFronWheelDrop   = 2,
00254         EventTypeLeftWheelDrop   = 3,
00255         EventTypeRightWheelDrop  = 4,
00256         EventTypeBump            = 5,
00257         EventTypeLeftBump        = 6,
00258         EventTypeRightBump       = 7,
00259         EventTypeVirtualWall     = 8,
00260         EventTypeWall            = 9,
00261         EventTypeCliff           = 10,
00262         EventTypeLeftCliff       = 11,
00263         EventTypeFrontLeftCliff  = 12,
00264         EventTypeFrontRightCliff = 13,
00265         EventTypeRightCliff      = 14,
00266         EventTypeHomeBase        = 15,
00267         EventTypeAdvanceButton   = 16,
00268         EventTypePlayButton      = 17,
00269         EventTypeDigitalInput0   = 18,
00270         EventTypeDigitalInput1   = 19,
00271         EventTypeDigitalInput2   = 20,  
00272         EventTypeDigitalInput3   = 21,
00273         EventTypeModePassive     = 22,
00274     } EventType;
00275   
00276     /// \enum IRCommand
00277     /// Values for sensor packet ID 27
00278     typedef enum
00279     {
00280         // Remote control:
00281         IRCommandLeft                   = 129,
00282         IRCommandForward                = 130,
00283         IRCommandRight                  = 131,
00284         IRCommandSpot                   = 132,
00285         IRCommandMax                    = 133,
00286         IRCommandSmall                  = 134,
00287         IRCommandMedium                 = 135,
00288         IRCommandLargeClean             = 136,
00289         IRCommandPause                  = 137,
00290         IRCommandPower                  = 138,
00291         IRCommandArcForwardLeft         = 139,
00292         IRCommandArcForwardRight        = 140,
00293         IRCommandDriveStop              = 141,
00294         // Scheduling Remote:
00295         IRCommandSendAll                = 142,
00296         IRCommandSeekDock               = 143,
00297         // Home Base:
00298         IRCommandReserved1              = 240,
00299         IRCommandRedBuoy                = 248,
00300         IRCommandGreenBuoy              = 244, 
00301         IRCommandForceField             = 242,
00302         IRCommandRedGreenBuoy           = 252,
00303         IRCommandRedBuoyForceField      = 250,
00304         IRCommandGreenBuoyForceField    = 246,
00305         IRCommandRedGreenBuoyForceField = 254,
00306     } IRCommand;
00307   
00308     /// \enum ChargeState
00309     /// Values for sensor packet ID 21
00310     typedef enum

00312         ChargeStateNotCharging            = 0,
00313         ChargeStateReconditioningCharging = 1,
00314         ChargeStateFullChanrging          = 2,
00315         ChargeStateTrickleCharging        = 3,
00316         ChargeStateWaiting                = 4,
00317         ChargeStateFault                  = 5,
00318     } ChargeState;
00319

00325         ModePassive = 1,
00326         ModeSafe    = 2,
00327         ModeFull    = 3,
00328     } Mode;
00329

00336         Sensors17to20                  = 2,
00337         Sensors21to26                  = 3,
00338         Sensors27to34                  = 4,
00339         Sensors35to42                  = 5,
00340         Sensors7to42                    = 6,
00341         SensorBumpsAndWheelDrops       = 7,
00342         SensorWall                     = 8,
00343         SensorCliffLeft                = 9,
00344         SensorCliffFrontLeft           = 10,
00345         SensorCliffFrontRight          = 11,
00346         SensorCliffRight               = 12,
00347         SensorVirtualWall              = 13,
00348         SensorOvercurrents             = 14,
00349 //      SensorUnused1                  = 15,
00350 //      SensorUnused2                  = 16,
00351         SensorIRByte                   = 17,
00352         SensorButtons                  = 18,
00353         SensorDistance                 = 19,

00355         SensorChargingState            = 21,
00356         SensorVoltage                  = 22,
00357         SensorCurrent                  = 23,
00358         SensorBatteryTemperature       = 24,
00359         SensorBatteryCharge            = 25,
00360         SensorBatteryCapacity          = 26,
00361         SensorWallSignal               = 27,
00362         SensoCliffLeftSignal           = 28,
00363         SensoCliffFrontLeftSignal      = 29,
00364         SensoCliffFrontRightSignal     = 30,
00365         SensoCliffRightSignal          = 31,

00379     /// Constructor. You can have multiple simultaneous Roomba if that makes sense.
00380     /// \param[in] serial POinter to the HardwareSerial port to use to communicate with the Roomba. 
00381     /// Defaults to &Serial
00382     /// \param[in] baud the baud rate to use on the serial port. Defaults to 57600, the default for the Roomba.
00383     Roomba(HardwareSerial* serial = &Serial, Baud baud = Baud57600);
00384 
00385     /// Resets the Roomba. 
00386     /// It will emit its startup message
00387     /// Caution, this may take several seconds to complete
00388     void reset();
00389 
00390     /// Starts the Open Interface and sets the mode to Passive. 
00391     /// You must send this before sending any other commands.
00392     /// Initialises the serial port to the baud rate given in the constructor
00393     void start();
00394     
00395     /// Converts the specified baud code into a baud rate in bits per second
00396     /// \param[in] baud Baud code, one of Roomba::Baud
00397     /// \return baud rate in bits per second
00398     uint32_t baudCodeToBaudRate(Baud baud);
00399 
00400     /// Changes the baud rate
00401     /// Baud is on of the Roomba::Baud enums
00402     void baud(Baud baud);
00403 
00404     /// Sets the OI to Safe mode.
00405     /// In Safe mode, the cliff and wheel drop detectors work to prevent Roomba driving off a cliff
00406     void safeMode();
00407 
00408     /// Sets the OI to Full mode.
00409     /// In Full mode, the cliff and wheel drop detectors do not stop the motors: you are responsible
00410     // for full control of the Roomba
00411     void fullMode();
00412 
00413     /// Puts a Roomba in sleep mode.
00414     /// Roomba only, no equivalent for Create.
00415     void power();
00416 
00417     /// Causes roomba to immediately 
00418     /// seek the docking station.
00419     /// No equivalent for Create.
00420     void dock();
00421 
00422     /// Starts the requirested built-in demo
00423     /// \param[in] demo The demo number. One of Roomba::Demo
00424     void demo(Demo demo);
00425 
00426     /// Starts the Cover demo
00427     /// Changes mode to Passive
00428     void cover();
00429 
00430     /// Starts the Cover and Dock demo
00431     /// Changes mode to Passive
00432     void coverAndDock();
00433 
00434     /// Starts the Spot Cover demo
00435     /// Changes mode to Passive
00436     void spot();
00437         
00438     /// Starts the Roomba driving with a specified wheel velocity and radius of turn
00439     /// \param[in] velocity Speed in mm/s (-500 to 500 mm/s)
00440     /// \param[in] radius Radius of the turn in mm. (-2000 to 2000 mm). 
00441     /// Any of the special values in enum Roomba::Drive may be used instead of a radius value
00442     void drive(int16_t velocity, int16_t radius);
00443 
00444     /// Starts the Roomba driving with a specified velocity for each wheel
00445     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00446     /// \param[in] leftVelocity Left wheel velocity in mm/s (-500 to 500 mm/s)
00447     /// \param[in] rightVelocity Right wheel velocity in mm/s (-500 to 500 mm/s)
00448     void driveDirect(int16_t leftVelocity, int16_t rightVelocity);
00449 
00450     /// Controls the LEDs on the Create
00451     /// \param[in] leds Bitmask specifying which LEDs to activate. ORed combination of ROOMBA_MASK_LED_*
00452     /// \param[in] powerColour The colour of the Power LED. 0 to 255. 0 = green, 255 = red, 
00453     /// intermediate values are intermediate colours
00454     /// \param[in] powerIntensity Power LED intensity. 0 to 255. 0 = off, 255 = full intensity
00455     void leds(uint8_t leds, uint8_t powerColour, uint8_t powerIntensity);
00456 
00457     /// Sets the digital output pins on the Cargo Bay Connector of the Create
00458     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00459     /// \param[in] out Mask specifiying which outputs to enable. ORed value ROOMBA_MASK_DIGITAL_OUT_*
00460     void digitalOut(uint8_t out);
00461 
00462     /// Sets the duty cycle for PWM outputs on the low side drivers. These can be use for PWM driving of
00463     /// motors, lights etc.
00464     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00465     /// \param[in] dutyCycle0 Duty cycle for low side driver 0. 0 to 128.
00466     /// \param[in] dutyCycle1 Duty cycle for low side driver 1. 0 to 128.
00467     /// \param[in] dutyCycle2 Duty cycle for low side driver 2. 0 to 128.
00468     void pwmDrivers(uint8_t dutyCycle0, uint8_t dutyCycle1, uint8_t dutyCycle2); 
00469 
00470     /// Sets the low side drivers on or off. On the Romba, these control the 3 motors.
00471     /// \param[in] out Bitmask of putputs to enable. ORed value ROOMBA_MASK_DRIVER_*
00472     void drivers(uint8_t out);
00473 
00474     /// Sends the requested byte out of the low side driver 1 (pin 23 on the Cargo Bay Connector).
00475     /// low side driver 1 can be used to drive an IR transmitter to send commands to other Roombas and Creates. 
00476     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00477     /// \param[in] data Data byte to transmit
00478     void sendIR(uint8_t data);
00479 
00480     /// Defines a song which can later be played with playSong()
00481     /// \param[in] songNumber Song number for this song. 0 to 15
00482     /// \param[in] notes Array of note/duration pairs. See Open Interface manual for details. 2 bytes per note, 
00483     /// first byte is the note and the second is the duration
00484     /// \param[in] len Length of notes array in bytes, so this will be twice the number of notes in the song
00485     void song(uint8_t songNumber, const uint8_t* notes, int len);
00486 
00487     /// Plays a song that has previously been defined by song()
00488     /// \param[in] songNumber The song number to play. 0 to 15
00489     void playSong(uint8_t songNumber);
00490 
00491     /// Requests that a stream of sensor data packets be sent by the Roomba.
00492     /// See the Open Interface manual for details on the resutting data.
00493     /// The packets will be sent every 15ms.
00494     /// You can use pollSensors() to receive sensor data streams.
00495     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00496     /// See the Open Interface maual for more details and limitations.
00497     /// \param[in] packetIDs Array specifying sensor packet IDs from Roomba::Sensor to be sent.
00498     /// \param[in] len Number of IDs in packetIDs
00499     void stream(const uint8_t* packetIDs, int len);
00500 
00501     /// Pause or resume a stream of sensor data packets previously requested by stream()
00502     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00503     /// \param[in] command One of Roomba::StreamCommand
00504     void streamCommand(StreamCommand command);
00505 
00506     /// Defines a command script which can later be executed with playScript(). You can clear the script by calling 
00507     /// script(NULL, 0);
00508     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00509     /// \param[in] script Array containing a sequence of Roomba OI commands.
00510     /// \param[in] len Length of the script in bytes.
00511     void script(const uint8_t* script, uint8_t len);
00512 
00513     /// Executes a previously defined script, 
00514     /// the last one specified by script()
00515     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00516     void playScript();
00517 
00518     /// Tells the Roomba to wait for a specified time.
00519     /// This command is intended for use in scripting only.
00520     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00521     /// \param[in] ticks The number of ticks to wait. Each tick is 15ms
00522     void wait(uint8_t ticks);
00523 
00524     /// Causes Roomba to wait until it has travelled the distance specified. 
00525     /// Roomba will not react to any inputs until the wait has completed. 
00526     /// Note that this does not cause the host arduino to wait, it only sends the wait comman to the Roomba
00527     /// This command is intended for use in scripting only.
00528     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00529     /// \param[in] mm Distance to wait for in mm
00530     void waitDistance(int16_t mm);
00531 
00532     /// Causes Roomba to wait until it has rotated through the specified angle.
00533     /// Roomba will not react to any inputs until the wait has completed. 
00534     /// Note that this does not cause the host arduino to wait, it only sends the wait comman to the Roomba
00535     /// This command is intended for use in scripting only.
00536     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00537     /// \param[in] degrees Angle to wait for in degrees
00538     void waitAngle(int16_t degrees);
00539 
00540     /// Cause the Create to wait for a specified event.
00541     /// Roomba will not react to any inputs until the wait has completed. 
00542     /// Note that this does not cause the host arduino to wait, it only sends the wait comman to the Roomba
00543     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00544     /// \param[in] type Event type to wait for. One of Roomba::EventType
00545     void waitEvent(EventType type);
00546 
00547     /// Low level funciton to read len bytes of data from the Roomba
00548     /// Blocks untill all len bytes are read or a read timeout occurs.
00549     /// \param[out] dest Destination where the read data is stored. Must have at least len bytes available.
00550     /// \param[in] len Number of bytes to read
00551     /// \return true if all len bytes were successfully read. Returns false in the case of a timeout 
00552     /// on reading any byte.
00553     bool getData(uint8_t* dest, uint8_t len);
00554 
00555     /// Reads the sensor data for the specified sensor packet ID. Note that different sensor packets have 
00556     /// different lengths, and it is the callers responsibilty to make sure len agrees with the expected 
00557     /// length of the sensor data. See the Open Interface mamual for details on sensor packet lengths.
00558     /// Roomba.h defines various enums and defines for decoding sensor data.
00559     /// Blocks untill all len bytes are read or a read timeout occurs.
00560     /// \param[in] packetID The ID of the sensor packet to read from Roomba::Sensor
00561     /// \param[out] dest Destination where the read data is stored. Must have at least len bytes available.
00562     /// \param[in] len Number of sensor data bytes to read
00563     /// \return true if all len bytes were successfully read. Returns false in the case of a timeout 
00564     /// on reading any byte.
00565     bool getSensors(uint8_t packetID, uint8_t* dest, uint8_t len);
00566 
00567     /// Reads the sensor data for the specified set of sensor packet IDs. Note that different sensor packets have 
00568     /// different lengths, and it is the callers responsibilty to make sure len agrees with the expected 
00569     /// length of the sensor data. See the Open Interface mamual for details on sensor packet lengths.
00570     /// Blocks until all len bytes are read or a read timeout occurs.
00571     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00572     /// \param[in] packetIDs Array of IDs  from Roomba::Sensor of the sensor packets to read
00573     /// \param[in] numPacketIDs number of IDs in the packetIDs array
00574     /// \param[out] dest Destination where the read data is stored. Must have at least len bytes available.
00575     /// \param[in] len Number of sensor data bytes to read and store to dest.
00576     /// \return true if all len bytes were successfully read. Returns false in the case of a timeout 
00577     /// on reading any byte.
00578     bool getSensorsList(uint8_t* packetIDs, uint8_t numPacketIDs, uint8_t* dest, uint8_t len);
00579 
00580     /// Polls the serial input for data belonging to a sensor data stream previously requested with stream().
00581     /// As sensor data is read it is appended to dest until at most len bytes are stored there. 
00582     /// When a complete sensor stream has been read with a correct checksum, returns true. 
00583     /// See the Open Interface manual for details on how the sensor data will be encoded in dest.
00584     /// Discards characters that are not part of a stream, such as the messages the Roomba 
00585     /// sends at startup and while charging.
00586     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00587     /// \param[out] dest Destination where the read data is stored. Must have at least len bytes available.
00588     /// \param[in] len Max number of sensor data bytes to store to dest
00589     /// \return true when a complete stream has been read, and the checksum is correct. The sensor data
00590     /// (at most len bytes) will have been stored into dest, ready for the caller to decode.
00591     bool pollSensors(uint8_t* dest, uint8_t len);
00592 
00593     /// Reads a the contents of the script most recently specified by a call to script().
00594     /// Create only. No equivalent on Roomba.
00595     /// \param[out] dest Destination where the read data is stored. Must have at least len bytes available.
00596     /// \param[in] len The maximum number of bytes to place in dest. If the script is actually longer than len
00597     /// only len bytes will be written
00598     /// \return The actual number of bytes in the script, even if this is more than len. By calling 
00599     /// getScript(NULL, 0), you can determine how many bytes would be required to store the script.
00600     uint8_t getScript(uint8_t* dest, uint8_t len);
00601   
00602 private:
00603     /// \enum PollState
00604     /// Values for _pollState
00605     typedef enum
00606     {
00607         PollStateIdle         = 0,
00608         PollStateWaitCount    = 1,
00609         PollStateWaitBytes    = 2,
00610         PollStateWaitChecksum = 3,
00611     } PollState;

00613     /// The baud rate to use for the serial port
00614     uint32_t        _baud;
00615         
00616     /// The serial port to use to talk to the Roomba
00617     HardwareSerial* _serial;
00618     
00619     /// Variables for keeping track of polling of data streams
00620     uint8_t         _pollState; /// Current state of polling, one of Roomba::PollState
00621     uint8_t         _pollSize;  /// Expected size of the data stream in bytes
00622     uint8_t         _pollCount; /// Num of bytes read so far
00623     uint8_t         _pollChecksum; /// Running checksum counter of data bytes + count
